moves.1. Nc3 Nc6 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Ne5 Ne4 4. Nxc6: My opponent is wise to me attacking his pawn
moves.10... d6 11. dxe5 fxe5: ...and remove it in exchange for my d-pawn.
moves.12. Bg5+: Now my bishop can attack the king.
moves.12... Be7 13. Bxe7+ Kxe7: Now we exchange bishops, forcing his king out of his comfort zone.
moves.15... Ba6 16. f4: I launch another assault on a pawn...
moves.19. Kd2: I decide to give my remaining rook more room to manoeuvre...
moves.19... c5 20. Rf1 Rxf1 21. Bxf1: ...which is used in a like-for-like exchange.
moves.21... c4 22. b3 Ke6 23. bxc4 bxc4: The board is getting emptier still...
moves.27... Kf7 28. gxh6: ...which I remove, although there's no chance of saving mine.
We exchange bishops, leaving another pawn ending.
moves.36... a6 37. a3: We advance our a-pawns forward, to go for a draw
moves.37... Kg7 38. Kg5: Now I have my opponent's g-pawn trapped.
moves.38... Kf7 39. h5 gxh5 40. Kxh5: Now there are only three pawns left.
moves.40... Kf6 41. Kg4 a5 42. a4: It looks set to end in a draw here...
moves.42... Ke6: but my opponent made a big mistake. What should he have done?
moves.43... Kd6 44. Kf5 Kc5 45. Kxe5 Kc6 46. K: My e-pawn will soon have a clear run.

gameName: No queens or knights... how will you do? II
